newsitem.title: USA: U.S. welcomes WTO ruling on Japanese liquor taxes.
newsitem.headline: U.S. welcomes WTO ruling on Japanese liquor taxes.

text.p: U.S. Trade Representative designate Charlene Barshefsky said Friday she welcomed a World Trade Organization arbitrator's decision that Japan should speed up compliance with an earlier ruling on liquor taxes.

"I am very pleased that the WTO reaffirmed the central principle of the WTO Dispute Settlement Understanding -- that members have an obligation expeditiously to comply with WTO rulings," Barshefsky said in a written statement.

"The arbitrator's decision that Japan shall have no more than 15 months to eliminate the discriminatory aspects of its liquor tax law is far shorter than the implementation sought by Japan," she said.
A WTO panel last year found Japan's tax regime for distilled spirits discriminated against imports and recommended Tokyo change its laws. An appellate body upheld the ruling in November.

Japan proposed bringing its laws into partial compliance 23 months after the ruling and full compliance in five years. In December, the United States asked a WTO arbitrator to determine a reasonable period of time for Japanese compliance.

"I believe it is now incumbent upon Japan, as a major trading nation and beneficiary of the multilateral trading system, to demonstrate its commitment to the WTO by fully complying with the rulings within the 15-month period established by the arbitrator," Barshefsky said.
